title: Overseas assets in bankruptcy.
question: I have about $60k in credit card that I would like to discharge in bk. However, I have a small property in my home country of El Salvador. If I discharge the credit cards in bk, will the trustee take the property and/or make me sell it? Can he force me to?
answers: As mentioned above, the asset must be listed. You may want to have it appraised (or otherwise evaluated) to determine its worth. In addition, you may want to determine if the laws of El Salvador define your interest for the purposes of a foreign bankruptcy.

Whether or not the trustee will liquidate the property depends on how much equity you have in that property and whether you have any exemptions to cover that equity. WIthout question, your interest in that property must be listed on Schedule A. Get a realistic fair market value appraisal, subtract any mortgages and that is your equity.

Bankruptcy requires review of your entire financial situation including all debts, income and assets. I highly recommend that you retain an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your jurisdiction to guide you through the complexities of bankruptcy law and procedure.

When you file a bankruptcy, you must list all your assets. However, not all assets are required to be sold. Some can be protected using exemption laws that are particular to your state of residence. If you have been living here long enough to claim California exemptions, it is possible that you might be able to protect your property.

If you cannot exempt all the equity in that property, the trustee will want that amount of money from you to give to your creditors. It may be possible for you to get those fund some way other than selling the property. Although the trustee will have a hard time actually forcing you to sell the property, if it is not protected and you do not give the trustee the value that is not protected, the trustee can ask the court to deny you your bankruptcy discharge (the permission to not pay your debts.)

You need to talk to a bankruptcy attorney who practices in LA and get some advice about whether you can protect this property before you file.
